creator: gabe@ghearing.com
text:
There is a problem with how the server identifies itself when using certain
browsers and IPv6. This is probably related to another bug
http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26005


If you go to http://[2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31:9886]/test/ (browsable empty
directory) in firefox/gecko the server identifies itself correctly with:

Apache/2.2.3 (Ubuntu) Server at 2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31:9886 Port 80

If you go to the same url in Safari you get:

Apache/2.2.3 (Ubuntu) Server at 2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31 Port 9886

creator: gabe@ghearing.com
text:
I guess I didn't explicitly state the problem... oops

The problem is that the last part of the ipv6 address is used as the port number
when using ipv6 and Safari.

I tested this on OS X 10.4 and Vista

Set up

UseCanonicalName on

then rinse and repeat.

This tells httpd not to trust the Host: header for its internal interpretation
of the host name.

The error is in safari

quote
  If you go to http://[2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31:9886]/test/ (browsable empty
directory) in firefox/gecko the server identifies itself correctly with:

  Apache/2.2.3 (Ubuntu) Server at 2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31:9886 Port 80

  If you go to the same url in Safari you get:

  Apache/2.2.3 (Ubuntu) Server at 2001:5c0:9744:0:230:84ff:fe31 Port 9886

/quote

Betting you dollars to donuts you found a Safari bug, and Safari is sending
the wrong Host: header.  Verify by capturing %{Host}i in your access log,
which will report what the client told the server.

Of course, if you did find a Safari bug, it will also manifest by matching to
the wrong named Virtual Host.  Let Safari folks know ASAP what you find out,
and close this report as INVALID here if the assumption proves correct.

Bill
